statement: E. Bindian Signalizingtime limit per test4 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutEveryone knows that long ago on the territory of present-day Berland there lived Bindian tribes. Their capital was surrounded bynhills, forming a circle. On each hill there was a watchman, who watched the neighbourhood day and night.In case of any danger the watchman could make a fire on the hill. One watchman could see the signal of another watchman, if on the circle arc connecting the two hills there was no hill higher than any of the two. As for any two hills there are two different circle arcs connecting them, the signal was seen if the above mentioned condition was satisfied on at least one of the arcs. For example, for any two neighbouring watchmen it is true that the signal of one will be seen by the other.An important characteristics of this watch system was the amount of pairs of watchmen able to see each other's signals. You are to find this amount by the given heights of the hills.InputThe first line of the input data contains an integer numbern(3 ≤n≤ 106),n— the amount of hills around the capital. The second line containsnnumbers — heights of the hills in clockwise order. All height numbers are integer and lie between 1 and109.OutputPrint the required amount of pairs.ExamplesInput51 2 4 5 3Output7

You are given $n$ ($3 \le n \le 10^6$) hill heights.  The hills are arranged in a circle.  Each hill has a watchman.  Two watchmen can see each other's signals if there is no hill taller than either of them between them along the circular arc connecting the two hills.  

Find the total number of pairs of watchmen who can see each other's signals. 


Input:

The first line contains an integer $n$. The second line contains $n$ integers representing the heights of the hills.

Output:

Print the number of pairs of watchmen who can see each other.

You are given a number of points arranged in a circle. Each point has a height.  Determine how many pairs of points can "see" each other, where a pair can see each other if there is no point with a higher height between them along the arc connecting the two points.
